titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Boone and Crockett Club Records circa 1885-2009
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Amy Weiss

publicationstmt.publisher: Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana-Missoula

repository.corpname: University of Montana, Mansfield Library, Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: This collection consists of the records of the Boone and Crockett Club which was founded in 1887 by Theodore Roosevelt and George Bird Grinnell and remains active today. Since its inception the Club has championed conservation causes and legislation, hunter ethics, and North American big game records keeping.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: In December 1887, a dinner was held by Theodore Roosevelt at his home in New York City and was attended by 10 of his friends, all hunting enthusiasts. Among the attendees were Dr. George Bird Grinnell, then editor of Field and Stream magazine, Roosevelt’s cousin, and Roosevelt’s brother. At the dinner Theodore Roosevelt proposed that the guests form an organization to promote sport with the rifle and work for the preservation of the large game of North America.

The first formal meeting of the Boone and Crockett Club was held in February 1888. Those present elected Theodore Roosevelt as President of the Club. The administrative duties of the Club would fall to an Executive Committee and Executive Officers. An editorial committee, with George Bird Grinnell as chair, was formed to prepare publications that promoted the Club’s conservation message. American Big-Game Hunting, by George Bird Grinnell and Theodore Roosevelt, was the first volume published by the Club and was released in October of 1893 by Forest and Stream Publishing Company. This volume was followed by several more game-related publications in collaboration with Forest and Stream Publishing Company.

A Committee on Admissions was formed at the Club’s first meeting. Membership was to be kept to 100 in order to keep administrative work to a minimum so that officers could be free to use their time for the goals of the Club. It was decided that regular membership requirements included killing “in fair chase” one specimen of three species of the larger game mammals of North America. Associate memberships were conferred upon men who did not meet these requirements but were prominent members of the hunting and conservation community. Another committee was appointed “to promote useful and proper legislation toward the enlargement and better management of Yellowstone National Park.” This committee, along with additional Club members, was instrumental in the passage of the Yellowstone Park Protective Act of 1895.

In 1910, a Game Preservation Committee was appointed with George Bird Grinnell as chair. This committee lent its support to the passage of conservation laws and policies such as the Alaska Game Law, the establishment of Glacier and Mt. McKinley National Parks, a bill to enlarge Yellowstone National Park, and many forest reserve and game refuge bills. The Club was able to lend effective support to conservation efforts due to its number of notable members, including Aldo Leopold, Gifford Pinchot, Theodore Roosevelt, Grinnell, Charles Sheldon, John F. Lacey, Stephen Mather, Jay N. “Ding” Darling, and many other prominent conservationists.

Between the years 1906 and 1922, Club member William T. Hornaday began collecting and cataloging exceptional big game heads. This collection became the National Collection of Heads and Horns and was displayed at the Bronx Zoo in New York City beginning in 1922. The Club assumed ownership of the National Collection of Heads and Horns in 1978 and the collection is currently available for viewing at the Buffalo Bill Historical Center in Cody, Wyoming.

The National Collection of Heads and Horns and the early conservation efforts of the Club sparked an interest in some members for big game records keeping. In the early 1930s, the Boone and Crockett Club began to assemble data on the maximum size attained by various species of North American big game. Prentiss N. Gray published the Club’s first big game records book titled Records of North American Big Game in conjunction with the National Collection of Heads and Horns in 1932. A second edition followed in 1939. These editions marked the first time that North American big game records were collected, authenticated, and published.

In 1947, the Club formed a Conservation Committee under the chairmanship of Richard Borden of the National Wildlife Federation. The Conservation Committee endorsed bills and produced policy statements for conservation, and was instrumental in saving the Florida Key Deer from extinction and establishing a Key Deer refuge in 1957. The Club also began supporting big game research through small monetary grants in 1948. Through oversight of the Conservation Committee, the Club contributed to numerous wildlife research projects including predator-prey relationships in Alaska, moose-wolf relationships on Isle Royale National Park, research on grizzly bears in Yellowstone National Park, and many others. In 1972, the Conservation Committee established an official Grant-in-Aid Subcommittee to oversee grant proposals. The Grant-in-Aid program continues today as the William I. Spencer Conservation Grants Program. The program is supported by endowments named for William I. Spencer and Tim Hixon.

In 1947, the Club held their first annual Big Game Competition. Supervision of the Competition was the responsibility of the Boone and Crockett Club’s Records of North American Big Game Committee, which was established in 1935. Winners were chosen by a judges’ panel based on skull length, antler or horn length, and basal circumference. The popularity of the competition and the records books led the Club to consider establishing an objective scoring system that could be used by trophy holders to measure their own specimens. In 1949, the Club appointed a committee, chaired by longtime Club member Samuel B. Webb, to develop the Official Scoring System for North American Big Game Trophies. In 1950, the system was adopted by the Club and soon became the standard for measuring North American big game. With the new scoring system in place, the Boone and Crockett Club remeasured the trophies in every category originally published in North American Big Game and published the results in a new edition records book in 1952. The system proved to be so effective it is still in use today in essentially the same form.

Editions of Records of North American Big Game were published every six to seven years after 1952 and 1993, when it was determined that records books would be published every six years. In addition to the original records books, the Club has published volumes on record elk, mule deer and whitetail deer. With collaborative oversight by Club-appointed committees and professional staff, the Boone and Crockett Club continues to publish books about hunting and conservation.

After the success of the initial Big Game Competition, the Boone and Crockett Club continued to hold annual Competitions until 1952, when competitions moved to every 2 years. In 1968, the Club moved the competitions to every three years. After the 14th North American Big Game Competition, held in 1971, the Club chose to change the name of their records program contests to the North American Big Game Awards to deemphasize the competition aspect of trophy hunting.

In 1973, the Boone and Crockett Club began collaborating with the National Rifle Association to sponsor records keeping. The tri-annual North American Big Game Awards Program was run from the Hunting Activities Department of the National Rifle Association by wildlife biologist William H. Nesbitt. The Hunting Activities Department was also responsible for processing entries into the Awards Programs and general records keeping. The Records of North American Big Game Committee of the Boone and Crockett Club retained responsibility for the polices of records keeping, including fair chase requirements, boundary identification, minimum scores, and species to include in the Awards Programs.

In December 1980, the collaboration with the National Rifle Association was dissolved and the Club assumed sole responsibility for the North American Big Game Awards Programs. In January 1981, the Club appointed William H. Nesbitt as Administrative Director for the Boone and Crockett Club’s Big Game Records program to work collaboratively with the Records of North American Big Game Committee. Currently, the administrative duties of Big Game Records are still shared by professional staff and the Records of North American Big Game Committee.

In 1985, with the help of a loan from The Nature Conservancy, the Boone and Crockett Club purchased the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch, located 10 miles southwest of Dupuyer, Montana on the Rocky Mountain Front, adjacent to the Bob Marshall Wilderness and Blackleaf Wildlife Management Area. The Boone and Crockett Foundation was formed and charged with managing and directing the Ranch, which the Club uses to conduct habitat research, conservation education programs, and land management demonstrations. In 2001, the Club completed construction of the Elmer E. Rasmuson Wildlife Conservation Center at the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch. The Center serves as a headquarters for the Club’s Lee and Penny Anderson Conservation Education Program, which offers education programs for people of all ages.

In 1986, the Boone and Crockett Club began publication of an Associates Newsletter which contained hunting and conservation articles and was distributed to Associate Members. This newsletter gave rise to the Club magazine Fair Chase in 1994. Fair Chase continues to be published quarterly and distributed to Associate Members of the Club.

In May of 1987, the Club entered into collaboration with The University of Montana to establish and direct research programs on the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch. Additionally, a Boone and Crockett Wildlife professorship was established at the university. In late 1990, the Club formed a hiring committee for the professorship and in 1992 Hal Salwasser was hired as the first Boone and Crockett Professor of Wildlife Conservation. In addition to the collaboration with The University of Montana, the Club currently has affiliated programs at Texas A&M, Oregon State University, and Michigan State University. In 2009, all physical assets, including the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch, were transferred from the Boone and Crockett Foundation to the Boone and Crockett Club. Although the Foundation no longer plays a role in the day-to-day management of the Ranch, the Foundation continues to raise funds to support and endow conservation education programs.

In 1992, the Boone and Crockett Club purchased the historic Old Milwaukee Railroad Depot on the Clark Fork River in Missoula, Montana, and relocated its headquarters there from Dumfries, Virginia. The Club continues to support its original mission of conservation and game preservation.

scopecontent.p: The Boone and Crockett Club Records have been divided into six Series, most of which have been further subdivided. The largest series in this collection is Series I: Administration, which contains early administrative correspondence and Executive Committee minutes, almost an entire run of the minutes of the Club’s annual meetings which began in 1893, and an almost complete run of Officer, Committee, and Membership booklets which were produced by the Club each year.

This collection also includes materials documenting the Club’s involvement in the big game conservation history of North America including general correspondence, Game Preservation Committee and Conservation Committee meeting minutes and correspondence, and materials documenting the Boone and Crockett Club’s Conservation Grants Program. The collection also contains materials that relate to the Boone and Crockett Club’s big game records keeping activities. These materials include documents pertaining to North American Big Game Records Competitions and Awards Programs, Records of North American Big Game Committee meeting minutes and correspondence files, the materials produced by the administrative staff of the Club’s Big Game Records Division, and materials related to the National Collection of Heads and Horns. Additionally, the records include documents related to the Boone and Crockett Club’s publications including administrative correspondence, planning materials and drafts of the Club’s records books, and drafts and correspondence related to the Club’s Fair Chase magazine.

accessrestrict.p: Researchers must use collection in accordance with the policies of Archives and Special Collections, the Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, and The University of Montana-Missoula. Grants with social security numbers are restricted. Records created 10 years ago or less are fully restricted.

userestrict.p: Researchers are responsible for using in accordance with 17 U.S.C. and any other applicable statutes. Non-exclusive copyright transferred to The University of Montana.

prefercite.p: Boone and Crockett Club Records, Archives and Special Collections, Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana-Missoula.

custodhist.p: The majority of these records were held by the Boone and Crockett Club at their headquarters in Missoula, Montana, until their transfer to Archives & Special Collections. A small box of early minutes and letters was deposited at the Archives in 1992. The bulk of the collection was donated in March of 2009. An addition to the Club's records was donated in 2011. A small collection of manuscripts, most by George Bird Grinnell, was added in 2017.

acqinfo.p: These records were transferred by the Boone and Crockett Club to the Archives in 1992. 2009 and 2011.

accruals.p: Additional records of enduring value will be transferred from Club headquarters as they become inactive.

processinfo.p: Materials in this collection were boxed and moved several times as the Club relocated its headquarters. Early Club records were stored with, and occasionally intermixed with, newer Club materials, making original order difficult to discern. The processor chose to divide the collection in logical series and then chose subseries based in large part on the existing structure of the organization. Runs, such as meeting minutes and publications, have been arranged chronologically. Other materials have largely been arranged alphabetically by folder title. Within folders the order of the material was retained. Materials related to the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch are contained within Series five, the Boone and Crockett Club Foundation, as they were originally created. In 2009, the Ranch and all other physical assets were transferred to the Boone and Crockett Club from the Foundation.

In 2011, an additional 8.5 linear feet was transferred from the Club to the Archives and integrated into the collection. The 2011 addition consists of materials related to the Boone and Crockett Club’s Conservation Grants Program. The order in which the Conservation Grants materials arrived in 2011 is different than the arrangement of the Conservation Grants folders in the set of records transferred to the Archives in 2009. Original order of the 2011 Conservation Grants materials was maintained and these records have been arranged as a Sub-subseries 2.1, Conservation Grants-2011 Addition. The 2011 Conservation Grants materials are arranged chronologically and original order within folders was maintained.

An additional1.0 linear feet came to the Archives from the Club via Sagamore Hill National Historic Site in 2011. These materials contained correspondence from Club secretary Kermit Roosevelt as well as materials related to big game record keeping. These materials have been integrated into the collection.

separatedmaterial.p: Philip L. Wright's papers related to his work as an official measurer for the Boone and Crockett Club were housed at Club headquarters and transferred to Archives and Special Collections along with the other Boone and Crockett Club materials in 2009. The Wright papers have been arranged as collection Mss 781.

bibliography.p: Trefethen, James B. An American Crusade for Wildlife

relatedmaterial.p: Two small collections of the Boone and Crockett Club’s records exist at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, New York. Archives and Special Collections at the Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library holds a collection of 58 oral histories generated by the Club (OH 297).

controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.

controlaccess.corpname: National Collection of Heads and Horns (U.S.)

scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to the administrative division of the Boone and Crockett Club, including general correspondence, officer and committee reports, meeting minutes, and materials related to the Club’s annual and other member meetings. The Series has been divided into twelve subseries, most of which have been subdivided further into sub-subseries.
Materials were grouped and interfiled by the processor to reflect the historic and current organization of the Club’s administration. Series are arranged alphabetically.

This subseries contains drafts of the Club’s constitution, by-laws, and incorporation. It documents the evolution of the Club’s by-laws as it contains correspondence regarding amendments and proposed changes dating from 1922 through 1993. Additionally, the series contains drafts and proposed amendments of the Club’s constitution and documents the evolution of the Club’s statement of purpose.

did.unittitle: Articles of Incorporation, Annual Registration Fee Assessment and Report
By-Laws and Charter Amendments, Correspondence and Memoranda
Statement of Purpose, Correspondence, Drafts, and Memoranda

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a run of general correspondence that documents the grassroots development of the Club. Although correspondence before 1891 that would document the founding of the Club is missing from the collection, early incoming and outgoing correspondence by founding Club members George Bird Grinnell and Theodore Roosevelt is included in this subseries. Additionally, the subseries contains materials that document the Club’s organizational development. Although this early correspondence does document the Club’s involvement in conservation and publications, specific correspondence regarding these subjects and big game records can be found in Series’ II, III, and IV.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains annual reports, ledgers, financial statements and correspondence, budget and tax materials, and materials related to bequests, gifts and legacies left to the Club by members in their wills. Materials such as cancelled checks, invoices and receipts dated post-1950 have been removed from the collection.

scopecontent.p: This subseries is divided into 3 sub-subseries and contains materials generated by the Executive Officers of the Club as well as other administrative committees. Materials include meeting minutes, correspondence, and reports.

This sub-series contains correspondence and reports created by individual members in their capacity as Executive Officers. The files arrived at the archives in folders which appear to contain materials from a single member and be limited to that member’s work as an officer of the Club. This sub-subseries was created to reflect that organization and original order within folders was maintained. Folders are arranged alphabetically by a member’s last name and present an almost complete picture of the role of Executive officers in the Boone and Crockett Club.

scopecontent.p: The executive committee of the Boone and Crockett Club was responsible for the general administration of the Club in conjunction with executive officers. This sub-subseries contains an almost entire run of executive committee meeting minutes dating from the Club’s earliest official meeting in 1888 through 2000. The Club would eventually transition from an executive committee to a board of directors, as is the current administrative organization.

scopecontent.p: Annual membership gatherings have been a cornerstone of the Club since its inception. The founding members believed that meetings and discussions between members kept the membership active and engaged in conservation issues. This subseries has been divided into three sub-subseries.

This sub-subseries contains the minutes of over 100 years of the Club’s annual meetings, which document membership involvement in the conservation, big game records keeping, and foundation goals of the Club.

scopecontent.p: In addition to the Club’s annual meetings, membership was often invited to attend casual meetings throughout the year. In the early years of the Club these meetings included presentations and slideshows of hunts by individual members. Later, the Club moved to have membership officially meet quarterly. This sub-subseries contains meeting minutes, correspondence, and planning materials for these events.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains minutes, correspondence, member mailers, membership election ballots, and Membership Committee materials. The subseries includes almost an entire run of Club yearbooks which document Club membership, officers, and committee involvement dating from 1906 to the present. The subseries also documents the process for obtaining regular membership as it includes membership endorsements and sponsorships.

scopecontent.p: Since its inception, the Boone and Crockett Club has been actively involved in conservation issues. This series documents the Club’s conservation activity from its early efforts to preserve game habitat through present-day efforts to fund educational activities. This series has been divided into five subseries and includes committee meeting minutes, correspondence, conservation grant requests and progress reports, and materials related to collaborative efforts and campaigns. Included in this series are materials related to the Club’s concept of Fair Chase.
Materials were grouped and interfiled by the processor to reflect the historic and current organization of the Club’s conservation efforts. Series are arranged alphabetically.

This subseries documents the conservation efforts of the Boone and Crockett Club that took place before the Conservation Committee was formed in 1947. Materials include correspondence, meeting minutes and reports from the Game Preservation Committee (of which George Bird Grinnell was chair) which documents the Club’s involvement in the designation of Glacier and Mt. McKinley National Parks. Also included are materials related to the Club’s conservation positions and policies. Absent are documents related to the Club’s involvement in conservation activities before 1904.

scopecontent.p: The Conservation Committee of the Boone and Crockett Club was formed in 1947 to address the Club’s conservation policies and actions. Various subcommittees were organized throughout the existence of the Conservation Committee and by 1994 the committee would include three standing sub-committees; one that oversaw the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch, one that worked with the Club’s university professorship programs, and one that oversaw grants-in-aid. By 1998, the Club had reorganized its committees and created the Hunter and Conservation Ethics Committee and the Position Papers Committee. The Ranch subcommittee, Professorship subcommittee and Grants-in-aid subcommittee became full committees. This subseries has been divided into four sub-subseries reflecting the work of the Conservation Committee.

Of particular interest within this sub-subseries is an almost complete run of the Conservation Committee’s correspondence and reports from 1947 through 1991. This sub-subseries also contains materials documenting the Club’s efforts to assist in the support of game refuges including their assistance in the creation of the Key Deer Refuge in Florida. Additionally, this sub-subseries contains a print designed by cartoonist and Club member Jay Norwood “Ding” Darling after the designation of the Key Deer Refuge.

scopecontent.p: The idea of fair chase was first proposed by Theodore Roosevelt and was present in the original Club constitution. It prohibited “killing bear or cougar in traps, crusting moose, elk or deer in deep snow, jacking, or killing them from a boat.” This subseries documents the evolution of the Club’s Fair Chase policy from the early 1960s through the late 1990s.

This subseries also includes materials related to the Club’s positions on a wide variety of topics from gun control, private property rights, and animal rights to the reintroduction of the wolf in Yellowstone National Park. Researchers will find materials documenting the development of these positions as well as responses from Club members to the Club’s position papers.

scopecontent.p: This series documents the Club’s big game records activities including the evolution of the management of the Big Game Records program as well as materials related to Official Measurers, the Sagamore Hill Medal Program, and the National Collection of Heads and Horns. This series has been divided into five subseries and includes committee meeting minutes, correspondence, Awards Program planning materials, menus, invitations and trophy certificates, as well as correspondence and inventories related to the National Collection of Heads and Horns.

Materials in this series arrived at the archives with no discernable original order and were grouped and interfiled by the processor to reflect historic and current organization of the Club’s big game records keeping activities and management. Series are arranged alphabetically and original order within folders was maintained.
Note: Trophy records and related photographs are maintained at the Boone and Crockett Club headquarters in their Big Game Records Department.

This subseries has been divided into three subseries and documents the administration of the club’s big game records program. Established in 1935, the Records of North American Big Game Committee supervised the Big Game Competitions until the Club began collaborating on Big Game Records with the National Rifle Association in 1973. At that time, the administrative duties fell to the North American Big Game Awards Program, which was housed in the Hunting Activities Department of the National Rifle Association. Currently, Big Game Records are administered in collaboration with the North American Big Game Committee and professional staff.
This subseries is divided into three sub-subseries which reflect the evolution of the management of Big Game Records at the Boone and Crockett Club.
This sub-subseries contains materials related to committee involvement in Big Game Records keeping.

did.unittitle: Committee - Records of North American Big Game

scopecontent.p: Sub-sub-subseries 1 includes materials produced by the Records of North American big Game Committee. In the years from 1935 through 1973, the Committee managed and oversaw the Club’s big game records-keeping efforts including the North American Big Game Awards Programs. Of particular interest are correspondence to and from Grancel and Betty Fitz that documents changes in the trophy scoring system. Additionally, this sub-sub-subseries contains meeting minutes, correspondence, trophy score sheets and materials related to scoring from 1939 through 1993. Absent are correspondence or meeting minutes created by the Committee before 1944.

scopecontent.p: Sub-sub-subseries 2 includes materials created by the Friends of North American Big Game Committee, a group that financially supported the North American Big Game Committee through subscriptions from the early 1950s through the early 1960s. Materials include correspondence, big game census figures and subscription information.

scopecontent.p: Sub-sub-subseries 3 includes materials produced by ad hoc committees related to Big Game Records. This sub-sub-subseries contains correspondence, memorandum and score chart revisions. Of particular interest are materials related to the development of the trophy scoring system by Samuel B. Webb that took place in the late 1940s and early 1950s. It is this scoring system that became the standard for big game trophy measurement after its development and is still in use today.

North American Big Game Awards Program

scopecontent.p: The North American Big Game Awards Program was a joint venture between the Boone and Crockett Club and the National Rifle Association to administer the Club’s big game records keeping responsibilities and Awards Programs. The North American Big Game Awards Program was in existence from 1973 through late 1980, when the partnership dissolved.
This Sub-subseries contains meeting minutes, correspondence, trophy score sheets and materials related to scoring.

scopecontent.p: This Sub-subseries contains materials created by the professional staff tasked with administering the Club’s Big Game Records program first in conjunction with the National Rifle Association, and since 1980, with the Boone and Crockett Club’s Records of North American Big Game Committee. Materials include correspondence with trophy owners as well as the Records of North American Big Game Committee and the National Rifle Association.

The materials in this Sub-subseries document the evolution of the Club’s Big Game Records program from being administered solely by members acting as volunteers to that of a partnership between paid staff and Club Committee members.

scopecontent.p: This Boone and Crockett Club has held North American Big Game Awards Programs since 1947. This Subseries contains materials from the first North American Big Game Competition in 1947 through the 24th North American Big Game Awards held in 2001. Materials include correspondence, awardees lists, banquet invitations, planning and promotional materials, programs, and judging materials.

scopecontent.p: Created in 1948, the Sagamore Hill Medal is given by the Roosevelt family in honor of Theodore Roosevelt, Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., and Kermit Roosevelt. It is awarded by the Big Game Final Awards Judges panel to an outstanding trophy of distinction. Only one is given at any Big Game Awards Program and one need not be awarded at each Program. This Subseries contains certificates, correspondence and committee materials related to the Medal Program.

Sagamore Hill Medal, Correspondence and Memoranda
Sagamore Hill Medals and Inventory, Correspondence

scopecontent.p: Official Measurers of the Boone and Crockett Club are volunteers who are certified by the Club to measure big game trophies. All trophies entered into a Records of North American Big Game Awards Program must be measured by a Boone and Crockett Club Official Measurer. Official Measurers have been utilized by the Boone and Crockett Club since the late 1940s.

This subseries contains correspondence between Official Measurers and Big Game Records professional staff, and the Records of North American Big Game Committee, and Official Measurer manual drafts. Of particular interest are materials related to Official Measurer training workshops developed by William H. Nesbitt, Administrative Director of the North American Big Game Records Program.

National Collection of Heads and Horns

scopecontent.p: The National Collection of Heads and Horns was established by Club member William T. Hornaday and was displayed at the Bronx Zoo in New York City beginning in 1922. The collection is currently held at the Buffalo Bill Historical Center in Cody, Wyoming and is maintained by the Boone and Crockett Club.

This subseries contains correspondence, committee reports, inventories dating from 1906 through 1978, promotional materials, and trophy prints. Of particular interest are the research notes of Lowell E. Baier which provide a history of the National Collection of Heads and Horns.

scopecontent.p: This series documents the Boone and Crockett Club’s outreach, publicity, promotions and publications. The series has been divided into four subseries and includes correspondence, drafts of publications, materials related to the Club’s Fair Chase magazine, the Club’s newsletter, the Club’s Associate’s Program and licensing and copyright materials.

Materials in this series arrived at the archives with no discernable original order to the files and were grouped and interfiled by the processor to reflect historic and current organization of the Club’s communications division. Series are arranged alphabetically.

An Editorial Committee was formed at the first official meeting of the Boone and Crockett Club in 1888, and the Club has published materials related to big game, conservation, and hunting since 1893. This subseries contains five sub-subseries which include materials related to the Club’s published materials.

This sub-subseries contains materials created by both the Editorial and Historical committees of the Boone and Crockett Club from the late 1950s through the late 1980s, as well as materials created by paid professional staff. Items include committee meeting minutes, correspondence, book orders, inventories, and publication lists. Absent are materials related to items published before 1910.

scopecontent.p: This sub-subseries is divided into two sub-sub-subseries and contains materials related to the books published by the Boone and Crockett Club.

did.unittitle: Books - Records of North American Big Game

scopecontent.p: The first edition of Records of North American Big Game was published by the Club in 1932 in conjunction with the National Collection of Heads and Horns. After 1952 Records books were published every six to seven years. In 1993 it was determined that Records books would be published every six years.

This sub-sub-subseries contains materials from the first edition of Records of North American Big Game, published in 1932, through the tenth edition published in 1993. Materials include correspondence, drafts, signatures, proofs, and big game score charts.

scopecontent.p: In addition to the Records of North American Big Game books, the Boone and Crockett has published editions on wild sheep, record whitetail and mule deer as well as record elk. The club has also published books on hunting and conservation. This sub-sub-subseries contains correspondence, drafts, proofs, mailers and reviews related to these publications.

scopecontent.p: The Boone and Crockett Club Associates Program was originally proposed by William I. Spencer in 1984. The program was developed to involve individuals who were interested in furthering the causes and work of the Club, but didn’t fit the requirements for regular membership as outlined in the Club’s constitution. An Associates Newsletter (which later developed into Fair Chase magazine) was developed to inform Associate Members of Club activities.
This subseries contains correspondence, candidate proposals, membership lists, and drafts and planning materials related to the Associates Newsletter.

scopecontent.p: In 1985 the Club formed the Boone and Crockett Club Foundation to manage and direct the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch. The Ranch was purchased by the Club to conduct research and educational activities related to big game and conservation. In 2009, all physical assets, including the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch, were transferred from the Foundation to the Club.

This series contains correspondence, the Foundation’s Board of Directors meeting minutes and by-laws, Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch materials, financial and fundraising documents, and materials related to the University of Montana Applied Research Program and Professorship.

Materials in this series arrived at the archives with no discernable original order to the files. Materials were grouped and interfiled by the processor to reflect historic organization of the Club’s Foundation. Series are arranged alphabetically and original order within folders was maintained.
This subseries contains annual meeting materials, correspondence, meeting minutes, and by-laws.

did.unittitle: Board of Directors and Officers Roster

scopecontent.p: This Subseries contains correspondence arranged in alphabetical order. Of particular interest are folders containing the correspondence from Club member Sherman Gray as these folders demonstrate and document the development of the Foundation.

Purchased in 1985, the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch was purchased to conduct habitat and wildlife research and educational programs. The Ranch was formerly managed by the Boone and Crockett Club Foundation. In 2009, the Ranch, along with all other physical assets, was transferred to the Boone and Crockett Club.
This Subseries contains case statements, correspondence, donation data, member mailers, research reports, and materials created by the Ranch Management Committee.

scopecontent.p: In 1987 the Club entered into a collaboration with The University of Montana to establish and direct research programs at the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Ranch. In addition, a Boone and Crockett Wildlife Professorship was established at the university.
This subseries contains the agreement with The University of Montana, correspondence, reports, and miscellaneous materials.
